pr_title: use job runtime limits as the runtime prediction when sensible

timeline.message:
reduce the minimum job runtime limit to 5s

... from 60s. This will allow jobs with shorter runtime limits to get
scheduled opportunistically even without predictions.

reduce the minimum job runtime limit to 5s

... from 60s. This will allow jobs with shorter runtime limits to get
scheduled opportunistically even without predictions.

timeline.bodyText: The description is probably incorrect: the more specific type is required? We do not change type here. It looks like a function composition. In that case this method could be generalized to accept an array of operators.
timeline.author: tbak

replies.bodyText:
By more specific type here I mean returning back a UnaryOperator rather than a Function (I’m not referring to the generic type T). The implementation is just a copy-and-pasta of Function#andThen(Function), but returning a UnaryOperator (more specific type) back.
Does it mane more sense now? Any suggestion on how to make the doc more clear?
replies.author: fabiokung

replies.bodyText: Makes sense. Maybe you can change it to: the more specific type (UnaryOperator) is required to avoid any confusion.
replies.author: tbak

timeline.author: tbak

replies.bodyText: Good catch. I was planning to update this as well and forgot it. I will get it fixed.
replies.author: fabiokung

replies.bodyText:
@tbak since we already check that state == TaskState.Started in DifferenceResolverUtils, I don't think we need to account for propagation delays. I made the fix to always use the same min from BatchJobExt, but that is just a safeguard.
Let me know what you think.
replies.author: fabiokung

timeline.message: ignore input attributes that are to be generated

cap runtime predictions to the job runtime limit

No point in predicting a runtime higher than the configured job runtime
limit. The runtime limit also act as a fallback when there are no
predictions available for a job.

reduce the minimum job runtime limit to 5s

... from 60s. This will allow jobs with shorter runtime limits to get
scheduled opportunistically even without predictions.
integration tests: support for scaling down agents

improve OpportunisticCpuSchedulingTest flakiness

... by avoiding "Stuck in Launched" situations

improve OpportunisticCpuSchedulingTest flakiness

... by avoiding "Stuck in Launched" situations
